text: if Builders built houses the way
programmers build software the first
woodpecker to come along would destroy
civilization it's true because when an
experienced programmer sees a bug they
typically feel nothing and do nothing
because fixing it will just create five
more bugs unfortunately not all bugs can
be ignored like when the oxygen tank for
Apollo 13 exploded or when your
production servers go down and cost your
company money today's video might change
your life because you'll learn how to
instrument collect and visualize
Telemetry data from your server thanks
to the magic of open Telemetry and the
LG TM stack not only will this help you
visualize and detect anomalies in your
software if you self-host on your own
VPS but most importantly these beautiful
data visualizations will make your boss
think you're highly productive to get
started there are five Technologies we
need to learn open Telemetry graphon
Prometheus Tempo and Loki it sounds
intimidating but it's easier than you
think let's put 60 seconds on the clock
to learn them open Telemetry is an
industry standard framework that
collects Telemetry data from software
things like metrics logs and traces
while being vendor agnostic so it works
with any programming language but to use
it you need a backend to store and
visualize the data and that's where lgtm
comes in G is for graphon and it's the
front end UI where you can visualize
your data you can also set up alerts
create dashboards and waste thousands of
hours here then P is for Prometheus and
it's a Time series database for storing
metrics T is for Tempo and it's a
database for storing traces while L is
for Loki a database for storing logs
metrics traces and logs are the Holy
Trinity of software observability a
metric consists of multiple data points
over time like CPU usage a trace tracks
the flow of requests across multiple
services to pinpoint bottlenecks and of
course logs are logs collectively this
forms the otel lgtm stack where data is
collected with open Telemetry stored in
these databases and visualized with
grafana if that all sounds complicated
don't worry I thought I was too stupid
to host something like this myself but
over the next few minutes we'll have our
own Telemetry framework up and running
like a true professional the first thing
we'll need is a server and today we'll
be using hostinger the sponsor of
today's video they provide a wide range
of Hosting services and in our case a
Linux virtual private server that's
perfect for this project and currently
they're running their biggest sale of
the year which will last until the 15th
of February the KVM 2 plan that I'm
using here today is available at $5.99
per month for 24 months a massive
discount of 67% and an incredible price
for the amount of horsepower you get two
CPUs and 8 GB of RAM on top of that
fireship viewers get an additional 10%
off using the discount code fireship but
now that we know where to get a server
we need to deploy the lgtm back end
luckily we won't have to install every
component individually and instead can
use this Docker image provided by
graphon if you're not already familiar
with Docker check out this video but you
don't have to be an expert because we
can spin up a server on hostinger with
Docker pre-installed it'll first bring
you to a setup page that looks like this
in fact now that we're on this page
you'll notice how we can self-host
almost anything here like WordPress
coolify super base a plain Linux server
or in our case we'll go with the Bas
Docker server which itself is just
Ubuntu with docker pre-install after we
go ahead and set that up we'll have the
option to set up SSH Keys which I would
highly recommend doing but for now all
you really need is a password for the
root Linux user now once the server is
up and running we can go to the
management dashboard and you'll find
instructions on how to connect with SSH
or a secure shell you go ahead and copy
your IP address then open up the
terminal and run SSH root which is the
user at that IP and now we have admin
access to the main frame of our hosting
your server at this point we can run the
docker command to verify that the docker
demon is and well looks good now let's
go ahead and run the docker image for
otel lgtm on the first run that'll take
a minute to pull the docker image from
the cloud but eventually you should have
grafana running on Local Host Now open
up the browser and go to your IP address
on Port 3000 and you should be able to
log into grafana as admin
congratulations you're now running the
lgtm stack everything looks good to me
but one disclaimer is that this Docker
image is not intended for production but
it is a great way to learn and
experiment with these Technologies but
grafana on its own is useless unless you
have it connected to a data source as
you can see under connections there's
all kinds of different ways we can
connect data in the cloud but in this
case we already have connections for
Loki Prometheus and Tempo we just need
to populate them with some data the best
way to do that is to run an application
with your favorite language and
framework for me recently that's been
Dino to run typescript on the server the
fireship pro members have a full course
for that as well but one feature you may
not know about is it's built-in
Telemetry support if you build a server
with Dino it'll automatically run traces
on your server and will also collect all
the console logs you forgot to remove
remove from your code but in addition to
that you can also create your own custom
traces and metrics like maybe I want to
create a metric in Prometheus that
tracks the average request time well I
can do that with open Telemetry by
creating a meter then I can send data to
that meter for whatever code handles a
request or it could Define a tracer to
track the life cycle of a function like
in this case I'm creating a span that
wraps a database query which would allow
us to keep track of errors and other
anomalies pretty cool but now it's time
to run this Dino app on my server I have
Dino installed here already is so I just
run the Dino Run command on this file
and now I can access this web
application on our IP address at Port
8000 and you'll see that usually we get
a successful request but every once in a
while we get an error without Telemetry
we'd have to wait for our users to send
us angry emails and then dig through our
server logs to find the error but now
thanks to the lgtm stack we can just go
straight into grafana and analyze
everything there let's click on explore
and first check out the logs the data
source here is Loki and you'll notice
that we have a large number of error
logs we can then filter them and start
to figure out where they're coming from
if we go to we can see all kinds of data
automatically being collected for
Prometheus and Prometheus has its own
query language that we can use as well
and then finally we can go to Tempo to
look at traces which provides a node
graph and histogram for the performance
on our server and that's really just the
tip of the iceberg when deploying a
Telemetry back end you also need to
think about security but luckily since
we deployed to hostinger their Vanguard
dos filtering and firewall config will
help guard against harmful traffic and
threats let me know if you want to see
more tutorials like this thanks for
watching and I will see you in the next
one
